title: What are the respective challenges and advantages of using common biometric ID methods such as fingerprints, facial scans, retinal scans, and voiceprints? Which one is best or is there a better one? - Quora

response.answer_text: Rather then view this as a detailed question, why don’t we ask a simpler question instead. What is the challenge of having users under go two forms of authentication as apposed to just one? You see there’s a trade off between security and convenience. Having a thumb print to access your phone isn’t necessary fun when it’s raining, or your sweating or the hardware which recognizes it starts to ware. It isn’t a matter of which one is best or is there a better one. If criminals really want to access data on a laptop there isn’t anything stopping them from simply holding a gun to the person and forcing them to open the device. Or taking a picture of someone’s thumb print to create the thumb print using 3D printing. Same thing with the voice metrics. I actually tried this service with my bank once and couldn’t get into my account afterwards. So it’s more about weighing the costs and benefits of each type of security.

What are the respective challenges and advantages of using common biometric ID methods such as fingerprints, facial scans, retinal scans, and voiceprints? Which one is best or is there a better one? The challenge is that ALL of them can be faked. ALL of them reduce to the generation of a random password that is then used. ANY damage to the person can destroy the identification - loss of fingers, damage to vocal cords, eye infections/degeneration… And you cannot replace them once they are duplicated… With the result that the best authentication is still a password. ANY of them can work find for an identification…. but they suck for authentication. Almost (but not quite) as bad as using an unencrypted channel for passwords as EVERY biometric is essentially public information…
